TL:DR - Straight up fun. 9/10 and a great addition to any VR games library.

4 different movement types to choose from, i personally go for teleportation and a mix of locomotion/turning because i have a small play area. I can sprint around with one vive touchpad and use the other to turn either a set amount of continuously like a thumbstick (which does invoke a bit of motion sickness in me, but its well worth it for being able to fine tune the direction you're running in without having to turn your body if you're limited for space like me) but then i use the teleport as a form of quick dash to escape enemies closing in on me.

Each weapon has a special ability which you charge up by doing damage, you can have 2 in your loadout. the dual crossbows is my favourite by far and the reloading feels amazingly satisfying. In fact the weapons in general are amazingly satisfying, an upward swing to the chin with a sword will send most unarmored enemies flying after a perfectly timed block. Alternatively, you could just stand in front of an enemy with your shield up and just wiggle your sword in their face for cheap shots.

Did i mention enemies are armored? and its not just a visual thing, you need to swing at their fleshy parts if you want to use a sword. if youre a bow user and they have a helmet, then its really satisfying getting that headshot through the gap in their faceplates.

Throwing weapons are a thing, you get an infinite amount with a cooldown like a special ability. my favourite are the 3 throwing knives positioned at the front of your waist as if tucked into a belt. you throw all 3 at once in a fan shape and it makes me feel like a rogue/assassin. I've also seen a magic bomb/potion type thing on another player but i havent unlocked it myself yet. It looks fun though.

Graphically, i love the style of it, and supersampling keeps it really sharp and clean to look at at, even distant objects.

The levels are technically randomly selected rather than "generated". Each level has specific tilesets that are chosen at random and connected together differently each time you load a level, a bit like the levels in warframe for example.

The difficulty seems pretty balanced so far, Some levels harder than others because the difficulty is level based rather than a single setting you pick at the beginning of the game.
Each difficulty make the enemies tougher and i think spawning more of them. This difficulty is then scaled further when you have more people playing together like in Diablo.

There are unique boss type enemies which, unlike normal grunts that only... grunt, the bosses will talk shit and be all intimidating which is amusing to hear at a distance when you're closing in on them and killing all their minions.

I can't speak too much for multiplayer, the most expirience i've had with that was when i was playing solo and some guy joined me halfway through a level and stuck around for a few more. He had unlocked more weapons than me and was clearly more experienced, however it doesn't throw off game balance at all as theres no leveling system that im aware of. he may have had different weapons but in terms of damage output, he was equally as useful as i was, making the combat more skill based than just being overpowered and destroying everything. 

Reviving dead teammates in multiplayer is a pretty tough thing. If you die mid-fight then you're probably dead for the rest of that encounter. You revive by holding your trigger over the teammates body and it fills up a meter. Which is pretty tough to do if you're being rushed by enemies. However, i have managed to do it when fighting against only archers. You just hide behind your shield blocking all arrows and revive them that way. 
Side note: the bar doesn't decay or lose progress at all if you stop reviving so the skilled player could probably run circles around the enemy, leading them away, then coming back to revive, then leading them away, then coming back to finish the revive. It doesn't take long at all to revive someone, but the enemy move surprisingly fast.



The only issue i've encountered so far, are the various Ballistas generated in the world. Sometimes they're in good positinos, other times not so much. Also, aiming them is a bitch to deal with if you're playing in a small standing area like me, even with thumbstick like movements available. I decided to just give up and run circles around the enemies firing my crossbows at them instead for the first "defend the area" type section.



Overall it's a solid underrated dungeon crawler, most VR games i feel are too expensive, with barely enough content to make your money worthwhile (the whole £1/$1 per hour of fun thing), But with this game being only £10, in theory that's 10 hours of fun, but im certain im going to play this for many many more, especially for the amount of content in it, especially since they're still updating it and adding more.

In my opinion, this game is more of an action game than a dungeon crawler, due to the frequency of enemies and lack or real exploring. This may or may not be your thing, so I suggest trying the game for an hour and refunding if you don't like it. 

pros: 
- there is a variety of weapons which all function very differently from one another. It encourages varied combat and allows for more tools to defeat the different types of enemies that have weaknesses to certain types and directions of attack.

-there are a lot of options for VR comfort, so it is possible to minimize nausea.

cons:
-the music is out of place contextually. It will be playing super epic music when I am just backtracking and nothing is happening. It makes it feel silly sometimes.

-The constant epic music and stream of enemies makes there be no contrast. It gets tiring and makes something that should be exciting become boring. 

-In the two missions I did, there was no variety in game mechanics. The missions functioned identically to one another. Go there, kill stuff, go home. 

______________________________________________________________________


There are some great aspects, like the variety of weapons and the promise of finding new equipment, and then there are some bad aspects, like the terrible sword combat. It has great potential. The idea is great, the direction it is heading is great, but it just isn't there yet.

This game is amazingly well done. Even in it's early access stages, it's the first VR title I've purchased that feels like a fully fleshed out game instead of just a tech demo or "a look into what VR is capable of" and the devs are actively working to improve the game with hotfixes and content updates.

The meat of the game is the adventure mode in which you traverse through procedurally generated dungeons to complete objectives while fighting through a horde of angry orcs. There's a good variety to the enemies in the game, each with their own strengths, and as you progress through the campaign you unlock new weapons to kill them with.

The other game mode is a wave defense where you protect your portal from an onslaught of orcs and shoot for the high score.

Where I think the game excels above other titles though is how it controls. They have several movement options:
[list]
[*]Teleport - Hold the button, point where you want to go and appear there.
[*]Point and Move - Press up on the right hand track pad to move where the controller is pointing.
[*]Single Stick - Use the right trackpad to move forward and back based on where you're looking.
[*]Dual Stick - Use the left trackpad to move forward/back, strafe left/right and the right trackpad to turn left and right.
[/list]
The dual stick is my personal favorite and feels the most immersive, allowing me to move freely while fighting. I feel more titles should adopt this system as I find the current standard of teleporting in most titles disorienting. The combat controls are also well done. Drawing the bow feels great and wading into orcs with my sword and shield is incredibly satisfying.

All that said, while the player controls are tight, the enemy AI could use a little bit of work. I've found on a few occasions that I can confuse the AI into a walking loop by dropping off a short ledge, allowing me to pick them off without much difficulty. Another problem I've encountered is that when walking around some of the more cluttered areas, I will clip on objects and end up getting stuck for a few moments while I navigate my way out of a pillar or a barrel.

All in all though I've had a fantastic time playing so far and look forward to what new content the devs are gonna add to the game. I definitely recommend giving it a try.

Trickster is a very promising vr game. You start in your hub / home fortress and use the portal to venture on missions in different zones. The combat is pretty arcadey with all the spells and hit effects flying around, but has a very satysfying feel. The procedural levels really add to replayability. A great break from the wave shooters out there.

The Gameplay.
The game takes place on procedural levels, where you punch your way through groups of enemies to reach your goal. There are four quests types available, with very different mechanics and skills needed to complete them. And whats most important - they are actually fun! Running from a flying crystal shooting death rays, ending a crow infestation or taking on an orc general - feels great. That gives great hope for the future content, but at the moment is a little repetitive after your first 10 or so levels. Looking forward for future updates.

The Visuals
The game is not realistic, by any means, but it has a very consistent, kinda toon art style. It fits well with the setting of the game. The floating islands are great to look at and you'll definitely find some epic vistas. Some FX look a little too flat up close and could be improved, but its not going to bother you in the middle of the combat.

The Enemies.
Simply put - well designed and fun to fight. The orcs vary vastly in terms of what they can do, while their designs make it easy make out squishies in the group. Some will shield others with their magic, some will perform some crazy jump attacks at you and there is that one that creates floating, life-sucking area denial orbs that you'll learn to avoid really quickly. While the animations in general look very fluid, the lack of ragdoll whatsover leaves bodies stuck in terrain if they died on a steep slope. Also, I want to be able to stab a dead orc. I need it in my life.

The development.
The developer is definitely a strong point here. Engaged with the community, sounds like a guy with a vision and pushes the updates consistently. Carry on like this and the game may just become one of the best fantasy games on vive.

Worth it? Ow yeah!
Overall, its a really fun title, well worth the 10$. If you enjoy light-hearted fantasy action and want a break from wave shooters, look no further!
